constructors.doc:
Creates a displaying the given animation. The does not assume a reference to the animation; you still need to unref it if you own references. will add its own reference rather than adopting yours.

Note that the animation frames are shown using a timeout with

G_PRIORITY_DEFAULT. When using animations to indicate busyness,

keep in mind that the animation will only be shown if the main loop is not busy with something that has a higher priority.
constructors.name: new_from_animation

constructors.doc:
Creates a new displaying the file filename. If the file isn’t found or can’t be loaded, the resulting will display a “broken image” icon. This function never returns null, it always returns a valid widget.

If the file contains an animation, the image will contain an animation.

If you need to detect failures to load the file, use GdkPixbuf.Pixbuf.new_from_file to load the file yourself, then create the from the pixbuf. (Or for animations, use GdkPixbuf.PixbufAnimation.new_from_file).

The storage type () of the returned image is not defined, it will be whatever is appropriate for displaying the file.
constructors.name: new_from_file

constructors.doc: Creates a displaying an icon from the current icon theme. If the icon name isn’t known, a “broken image” icon will be displayed instead. If the current icon theme is changed, the icon will be updated appropriately.
constructors.name: new_from_gicon

constructors.doc: Creates a displaying an icon from the current icon theme. If the icon name isn’t known, a “broken image” icon will be displayed instead. If the current icon theme is changed, the icon will be updated appropriately.
constructors.name: new_from_icon_name

constructors.doc:
Creates a displaying an icon set. Sample stock sizes are

GTK_ICON_SIZE_MENU, #GTK_ICON_SIZE_SMALL_TOOLBAR. Instead of using

this function, usually it’s better to create a , put your icon sets in the icon factory, add the icon factory to the list of default factories with , and then use . This will allow themes to override the icon you ship with your application.

The does not assume a reference to the icon set; you still need to unref it if you own references. will add its own reference rather than adopting yours.
constructors.name: new_from_icon_set

constructors.doc:
Creates a new displaying pixbuf. The does not assume a reference to the pixbuf; you still need to unref it if you own references. will add its own reference rather than adopting yours.

Note that this function just creates an from the pixbuf. The created will not react to state changes. Should you want that, you should use .
constructors.name: new_from_pixbuf

constructors.doc:
Creates a new displaying the resource file resource_path. If the file isn’t found or can’t be loaded, the resulting will display a “broken image” icon. This function never returns null, it always returns a valid widget.

If the file contains an animation, the image will contain an animation.

If you need to detect failures to load the file, use GdkPixbuf.Pixbuf.new_from_file to load the file yourself, then create the from the pixbuf. (Or for animations, use GdkPixbuf.PixbufAnimation.new_from_file).

The storage type () of the returned image is not defined, it will be whatever is appropriate for displaying the file.
constructors.name: new_from_resource

constructors.doc: Creates a displaying a stock icon. Sample stock icon names are #GTK_STOCK_OPEN, #GTK_STOCK_QUIT. Sample stock sizes are #GTK_ICON_SIZE_MENU, #GTK_ICON_SIZE_SMALL_TOOLBAR. If the stock icon name isn’t known, the image will be empty. You can register your own stock icon names, see and .
constructors.name: new_from_stock

constructors.doc: Creates a new displaying surface. The does not assume a reference to the surface; you still need to unref it if you own references. will add its own reference rather than adopting yours.
constructors.name: new_from_surface

doc:
The widget displays an image. Various kinds of object can be displayed as an image; most typically, you would load a GdkPixbuf.Pixbuf ("pixel buffer") from a file, and then display that. There’s a convenience function to do this, , used as follows: |[<!-- language="C" --> GtkWidget *image; image = gtk_image_new_from_file ("myfile.png"); ]| If the file isn’t loaded successfully, the image will contain a “broken image” icon similar to that used in many web browsers. If you want to handle errors in loading the file yourself, for example by displaying an error message, then load the image with GdkPixbuf.Pixbuf.new_from_file, then create the with .

The image file may contain an animation, if so the will display an animation (GdkPixbuf.PixbufAnimation) instead of a static image.

is a subclass of , which implies that you can align it (center, left, right) and add padding to it, using methods.

is a “no window” widget (has no Gdk.Window of its own), so by default does not receive events. If you want to receive events on the image, such as button clicks, place the image inside a , then connect to the event signals on the event box.

Handling button press events on a .

|[<!-- language="C" --> static gboolean button_press_callback (GtkWidget event_box, GdkEventButton event, gpointer data) { g_print ("Event box clicked at coordinates %f,%f\n", event->x, event->y);

// Returning TRUE means we handled the event, so the signal
// emission should be stopped (don’t call any further callbacks
// that may be connected). Return FALSE to continue invoking callbacks.
return TRUE;

}

static GtkWidget create_image (void) { GtkWidget image; GtkWidget *event_box;

image = gtk_image_new_from_file ("myfile.png");

event_box = gtk_event_box_new ();

gtk_container_add (GTK_CONTAINER (event_box), image);

g_signal_connect (G_OBJECT (event_box),
                  "button_press_event",
                  G_CALLBACK (button_press_callback),
                  image);

return image;

} ]|

When handling events on the event box, keep in mind that coordinates in the image may be different from event box coordinates due to the alignment and padding settings on the image (see ). The simplest way to solve this is to set the alignment to 0.0 (left/top), and set the padding to zero. Then the origin of the image will be the same as the origin of the event box.

Sometimes an application will want to avoid depending on external data files, such as image files. GTK+ comes with a program to avoid this, called “gdk-pixbuf-csource”. This library allows you to convert an image into a C variable declaration, which can then be loaded into a GdkPixbuf.Pixbuf using GdkPixbuf.Pixbuf.new_from_inline.

methods.doc: Gets the GdkPixbuf.PixbufAnimation being displayed by the . The storage type of the image must be .empty or .animation (see ). The caller of this function does not own a reference to the returned animation.
methods.name: get_animation

methods.doc: Gets the Gio.Icon and size being displayed by the . The storage type of the image must be .empty or .gicon (see ). The caller of this function does not own a reference to the returned Gio.Icon.
methods.name: get_gicon

methods.doc: Gets the icon name and size being displayed by the . The storage type of the image must be .empty or .icon_name (see ). The returned string is owned by the and should not be freed.
methods.name: get_icon_name

methods.doc: Gets the icon set and size being displayed by the . The storage type of the image must be .empty or .icon_set (see ).
methods.name: get_icon_set

methods.doc: Gets the GdkPixbuf.Pixbuf being displayed by the . The storage type of the image must be .empty or .pixbuf (see ). The caller of this function does not own a reference to the returned pixbuf.
methods.name: get_pixbuf

methods.doc: Gets the pixel size used for named icons.
methods.name: get_pixel_size

methods.doc: Gets the stock icon name and size being displayed by the . The storage type of the image must be .empty or .stock (see ). The returned string is owned by the and should not be freed.
methods.name: get_stock

methods.doc: Gets the type of representation being used by the to store image data. If the has no image data, the return value will be .empty.
methods.name: get_storage_type

methods.doc: Causes the to display the given animation (or display nothing, if you set the animation to null).
methods.name: set_from_animation

methods.doc: Sets the pixel size to use for named icons. If the pixel size is set to a value != -1, it is used instead of the icon size set by .
methods.name: set_pixel_size

name: Image

properties.doc: The GIcon displayed in the GtkImage. For themed icons, If the icon theme is changed, the image will be updated automatically.
properties.name: gicon

properties.doc: The name of the icon in the icon theme. If the icon theme is changed, the image will be updated automatically.
properties.name: icon-name

properties.doc: The "pixel-size" property can be used to specify a fixed size overriding the property for images of type .icon_name.
properties.name: pixel-size

properties.doc: A path to a resource file to display.
properties.name: resource

properties.doc: Whether the icon displayed in the GtkImage will use standard icon names fallback. The value of this property is only relevant for images of type .icon_name and .gicon.
properties.name: use-fallback
